伯里子 (7th century) from the state of Chu, mostly referred to as Bo Lixi 百里奚 or as Bo Lizi 百里子, was a cowherd from the tiny state of Yu 虞, and according to HSWZ 8.25 even a beggar, who was taken prisoner when >Duke Xian of Jin 晉獻公 (r. 676-651) destroyed that small state of Yu in 655. Bo Lizi was repeatedly resold (百里奚轉鬻), as HNZ 19.3b puts it memorably. SJ 83.2743 reports that he was a beggar until he was brought into politics by Duke Mu of Qin 秦穆公 (r. 659 - 621). He sold himself for for five sheep-skins to Duke Mu of Qin according to HSWZ 7.6. SJ 39.1653 has him in conversation with Duke Mu of Qin. A remarkable case of social mobility in ancient China, he became a reform-minded prime minister who helped that duke dominate the neighbouring states. [HNZ 10.11b] He is often mentioned on a par with >Guan Zhong 管仲 (d. 643) who played a similar role in the service of >Duke Huan of Qi 齊桓公.
Bào Qiăn 暴譴, the prime minister of Han 韓, who is is mentioned along with >Bai Gui 白圭, is unattested outside HF.
Bi Fang (deity)

Bó Xuăn 伯咺 (d. 680) from the state of Zheng, also known as Bo Yuan 伯原, Bo Fuyuan 伯父原, or Yuan Fan 原繁, was a dignitary with a long military family tradition. He is first mentioned in ZUO Yin 5 for his participation in the defence of the state of Zheng against an attack from Wei 魏. In spite of his military merits in the defence of Zheng for the years 718 and 707, he is accused of lack of loyalty by >Duke Li of Zheng 鄭厲公 (reigned 701-697 and 680-673) in connection with the latter’s return to power in 680, and he is made to commit suicide in the same year. [ZUO Huan 5, and Zhuang 14]
Diviner Pí 卜皮 (fourth cent.), was the commander of a district in Wei 魏, and a contemporary of >King Hui of Wei 魏惠王 (r. 370 – 335) He is unattested outside HF 30.27.
Bŭzĭ 卜子 (dates uncertain), presumably a diviner, cannot be identified with certainty and seems unattested outside HF 32.30.

Duke Huan of Cai 蔡桓公 (r. 714-695), posthumous polite designation for Marquis Huan of Cai 蔡桓侯. He is recorded to have joined an attack against the state of Zheng in CQ Huan 16 (696), and his death is recorded in CQ Huan 17.
Cài Nu 蔡女 was a daughter of >Marquis Mu of Cai 蔡穆侯 (r. 674 - 646) and seems to be unattested outside HF 32.25.
Cài Yù 蔡嫗 (fl. ca. 300), the wu 巫 ‘shamaness’ in the house of >Bo Yi 薄疑 (fl. 300) seems unattested outside HF.
Chén Xiè Yě, 陳泄冶 (fl. late 7th century) was a minister to >Duke Ling of Chen 陳靈公 who was executed for remonstrating against his ruler. [SY 1.4]
Shēn Xū 申胥 from Chŭ is on record as an adviser to King Fuchai of Wu 吳王夫差 (r. 495 - 473). GY Wuyu records several episodes of this kind. [JIAYU 37.2; YUEJUESHU 6] HF 44.

Chén Xū 陳需 (4th century), also known as Tián Xū 田需, served for a time as a prime minister to >King Huì of Wèi 魏惠王 (r. 370 – 335) and is described in intrigues and conversations with that king in ZGC under the name Tian Xu 田需. He is not mentioned anywhere in ZUO. [ZGC Qi 4 and Wei 2.7, 2.12, 2.13； HF 31.30；SJ 44.1851]

Chéng Huān 成驩 (early 3rd century), sometimes written 成歡, was a courtier in the state of Qi 齊, probably during the reign of >King Min of Qi 齊湣王 (323 – 284, r. 300 – 284). Chéng Huān is said to have thought the state of Qí was weak as a result of excessive kind-heartedness. He is unattested outside HF 30.26.

Chéng Huān 成驩 (early 3rd century), also written 成歡, was a courtier in the state of Qi 齊, probably during the reign of >King Min of Qi 齊湣王 (323 – 284, r. 300 – 284). Chéng Huān is said to have thought the state of Qí was weak as a result of excessive kind-heartedness. He is unattested outside HF 30.26.
Chéng Jū 成駒 was a leader of the Sān Miáo 三苗, an ancient southern people mentioned in several ancient sources. This leader’s name is unattested outside HF.

King Lì of Chǔ 楚厲王 is a Western Zhou time figure who comes up twice in HF, but who is not mentioned elsewhere in our main historical sources concerning the period. It has been surmised that the name may be a posthumous appellation for King Fenmao of Chu 楚蚡冒王 (reigned 757 -740). But this adds little to our understanding of the HF text.

Chūnshēn Jūn 春申君 (7th – 6th century) was a younger brother of >King Zhuang of Chu 楚莊王 (r. 613-591). We know nothing about him, though he cannot have been the famous Chunshen Jun 春申君 whose name was Huáng Xiē 黃歇 and who died in 238.

Dà Chéngniú 大成牛 (4th century)is taken to be referred to in ZGC 26.2 as a prime minister in Zhào, albeit under the name Great Cheng Wu 大成午. He became prime minister under Marquis Cheng of Zhao 趙成侯 (r. 374 – 349) and was a contemporary of the legalist >Shen Buhai 申不害 (c. 400 – ca. 332).
Dài Huān 戴驩 (fl. ca. 370) was a Senior Stewart 大宰 in Song 宋 and must have been a contemporary of Huang Xi 皇喜 . He is unattested outside HF. [HF 30.44; 30.46]

Dŏng Bùshì 董不識, also known as Dong Buzi 董不訾 appears to have been one of a group of seven associates of >Emperor Shun 舜. He is unattested in ancient literature outside HF 44. [Zhang Jue 2000, p. 1080, note 1]

Gāo Hè 高赫 (fourth cent.) served with distinction in the household of >Zhào Xiāngzĭ 趙襄子 (r. 370 - 335), along with >Zhāng Mèngtán 張孟談. The story of his participation in the siege of Jinyang 晉陽 in 453 is commonly referred to in the literature.[LSCQ 36.7; HNZ 13.22bff, 18.13bff; SY 6.2]

Gōngchéng Wúzhèng 公乘無正(4th century). HF 22 describes him as a courtier in the state of Han 韓 and as a contemporary of >Zhang Qian 張譴 (4th century) and >Gongzi Shiwo 公子食我 (4th century). He is unattested in other sources.

Gōngshū Cuó 公叔痤 (d. 361) was prime minister in Wei 魏. When he was ill and was being asked to recommend a successor he recommended >Gongsun Yang 公孫鞅, thus launching one of the most important political careers in ancient China best known as the Lord of Shang 商君. [LSCQ 11.5; ZGC Wei 1; Zhang Jue 2000, p. 57, note 23]

Gōngzhòng Péng 公仲朋 (late 4th cent.), also known as Han Peng 韓朋, as Gongzhong 公仲 and Gongzhong Chi 公仲侈 [SJ 71.2312. See also SJ ed. Han Zhaoqi p. 3613, note 5] was a favourite of King Xuanhui of Han 韓宣惠王 (r. 332 – 312). He came to serve as the prime minister of Han 韓. [SJ 71 passim; ZGC passim]

Gōngzhòng Péng 公仲朋 (late 4th cent.), also known as Han Peng 韓朋, as Gongzhong 公仲 and Gongzhong Chi 公仲侈 [SJ 71.2312. See also SJ ed. Han Zhaoqi p. 3613, note 5] was a favourite of King Xuanhui of Han 韓宣惠王 (r. 332 – 312). He came to serve as the prime minister of Han 韓. [SJ 71 passim; ZGC passim]

Gōngzhòng Péng 公仲朋 (late 4th cent.), also known as Han Peng 韓朋, as Gongzhong 公仲 and Gongzhong Chi 公仲侈 [SJ 71.2312. See also SJ ed. Han Zhaoqi p. 3613, note 5] was a favourite of King Xuanhui of Han 韓宣惠王 (r. 332 – 312). He came to serve as the prime minister of Han 韓. [SJ 71 passim; ZGC passim]

Prince Kāifāng 公子開方 (7th century) was a prince from Wèy 衛 but came to serve as an official in the court of >Duke Huan of Qi 齊桓公. His personality aroused sustained interest on the part of the compilers of GUAN. Recent archaeological evidence [QINGHUA 2] mentions Qi Fang 啓方 who is taken to be identical with Prince Kaifang, and who in that text is said to be none other than > Marquis Wen of Wey 衛文侯. [GUAN 18, 20 and 26]

Prince Mùyí 公子目夷 (7th century) was a son by a concubine of Duke Huan of Song 宋桓公 (r. 681-651), and Duke Huan wanted to establish him as a successor. He was said to have declined the offer of the throne in 642. [HSWZ 10.7] The story is also related in SY 4.8 and ZUO Xi 6] In ZUO Xi 21, Prince Muyi unsuccessfully recommends to Duke Xiang of Song 宋襄公 (r. 650 – 637) to attack the Chu army as it is crossing a river, and this episode is briefly referred to in SY 8.2 (ed. Wang Ying p. 314).

sense.def: Gōngzĭ Shíwŏ (4th century) was a prince in the state of Han 韓, mentioned with >Zhang Qian 張譴 and >Gongcheng Wuzheng 公乘無正 in HF 22.21. In LSCQ 18.1 he is presented in conversation with Marquis Zhao of Han 韓昭侯 (r. 358 – 333).

Prince Zăi 公子宰. Prince Zăi of Zhōu 周公子宰 (late 5th cent.), also called Prince Zhāo 公子朝, was the eldest son of >King Wēi of Zhōu 周威王 (r. 425 - 402) also known as King Weilie of Zhou 周威烈王. He is unattested outside HF.
